applies to the bankruptcy court’s severance of these counterclaims. In its motions to sever, Kaiser moved under Bankruptcy Rules 7012, 7013, 7021 and 7042. Bankruptcy Rules 7012 and 7013 do not address the severance of claims or counterclaims. Rule 7012 simply provides for the form and time periods for filing answers and answers to cross-claims and for the admission or denial of the designation of core and non-core matters. Bankruptcy Rule 7013 is similarly unhelpful. While it concerns the filing of counterclaims and cross-claims, the rule does not cover their severance. The rule simply makes Fed.R.Civ.P. 13 applicable to bankruptcy adversary proceedings, with the exception that a party sued by a debtor in possession or a trustee need not state as a counterclaim any prepetition claim (<HOLDING>). We conclude that the broad legal views outlined in Otis II are reasonably defensible approaches for determining when plant re-locations are mandatory bargaining subjects under the NLRA. IV. Analysis of the Present Case Having determined that Otis II is not fatally flawed on its face, our inquiry is not over. When it comes to sentences for bank robbery, they can either be served one after another or at the same time. But the law doesn’t allow a court to decide if any future sentences should be served this way. Basically, if you're already serving time when new sentences are given, then the court can decide if the new ones should be added on consecutively or concurrently. But if you're not already serving another sentence, the court can't make that call. Other courts have come to the same conclusion. See Romandine v. United States and United States v. Quintero.

Even if someone gives general consent to search without specific limits, the search must still be reasonable. Nabarro, 55 Haw. 583, 525 P.2d 573 (1974)).

The Bankruptcy Court's decision to sever these counterclaims is governed by specific Bankruptcy Rules, yet Kaiser’s motions to sever under Bankruptcy Rules 7012, 7013, 7021, and 7042 were misplaced. Bankruptcy Rules 7012 and 7013 are irrelevant to severance; Rule 7012 handles the format and timing for filing answers and cross-claim responses, as well as core and non-core matter designations. Rule 7013, while addressing counterclaims and cross-claims, does not cover their severance and merely applies Fed.R.Civ.P. 13 to bankruptcy proceedings, with a note that a party being sued by a debtor-in-possession or trustee isn't required to counterclaim prepetition claims. Therefore, Kaiser’s reliance on these rules is unfounded and does not support severance.

For example, in Herbes, 180 Ill.App.3d at 698-99, 129 Ill.Dec. 480, 536 N.E.2d 164, the court found that the plaintiff's counsel, who was suing a township over its open-space acquisition program, couldn't represent the plaintiff. This was because the same lawyer had previously had an attorney-client relationship with the township when it considered hiring him for representation in that same program, showing the township’s intention to hire him and thus share details about the program freely. Similarly, in Hughes, 565 F.Supp. at 670, the court reached a related conclusion, as did the court in Int’l. Paper Co. v. Lloyd Manufacturing Co.

The impact on procreation and child-rearing practices among opposite-sex couples, whether married or not, is a topic of heated debate. In Perry II, the court observed that there's no logical reason to believe that stripping same-sex couples of the title "marriage" would somehow encourage opposite-sex couples to be more responsible about having children. Indeed, some individuals may have a bias towards preferring biological parents over other types of couples, but this bias finds no support in federal or state law. There's no evidence that the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) changes any laws related to childbearing, procreation, or family structure. As it stands, the argument that redefining marriage would support better child-rearing practices holds no ground in today's legal framework.

Regarding the subject of the gates at Lemmon Avenue Terminal, the plaintiffs are entitled to a partial summary judgment. Specifically, they argue that the Wright Amendment Reform Act's (WARA) requirement for the city of Dallas to demolish the passenger gates infringes upon Love Terminal Partners' pre-existing property rights. This right includes the ability to exclude others, including the city of Dallas, from entering and destroying these gates. Relief can be sought in any situation where a judgment does not align with the statute. Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b)(1), a court may offer relief from a judgment due to “mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect,” but the motion must be filed within one year of the judgment's entry. In this case, the district court acknowledged, and it is clearly evident, that the error was due to inadvertence. Consequently, Rule 60(b)(1) and its one-year limitation period are applicable. The district court attempted to avoid the stringent one-year limit by interpreting Rule 60(b)(6) as allowing for extended relief. However, since Rule 60(b)(1) clearly applies and the motion for relief was made after more than one year from the entry of judgment, we must reject this approach. Finally, we firmly reject the appellees' arguments.

Plain Dealer Publ’g Co., 486 U.S. 750, 757 (1988) and Freedman v. Maryland, 380 U.S. 51 (1965). Prior restraints on expression, especially in public forums, must face rigorous scrutiny to ensure they do not infringe on fundamental freedoms. The court in FW/PBS, Inc. v. Dallas, 493 U.S. 215, 226 (1990) emphasized this by citing numerous cases where stringent standards were applied.

Moreover, the context in which a prior restraint is applied can impact the level of scrutiny, as noted by the Seventh Circuit in Milwaukee Police Ass’n v. Jones, 192 F.3d 742, 749 (1999). While prior restraints in nonpublic forums can be upheld, they must be both reasonable and neutral regarding viewpoints, a principle affirmed in Cornelius v. NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, 473 U.S. 788, 813 (1985) and Muller v. Jefferson Lighthouse Sch., 98 F.3d. These precedents underscore the necessity for clear guidelines to prevent arbitrary and potentially biased restrictions on expression.

The clergy held more expertise than civil courts in interpreting and resolving matters of ecclesiastical law and religious faith. To prove that a defendant knowingly possessed an explosive under § 842(i)(1), the Government does not need to show that the device was capable of exploding. It only needs to demonstrate that the defendant knew he had dynamite or another chemical compound, mixture, or device primarily designed to explode.

Mr. Markey argues that he should be exonerated because he believed in good faith that the dynamite could not explode. However, this argument seems to show a misunderstanding of the law—essentially, "I thought the law was different." Such arguments are easily dismissed, as seen in United States v. Capps and United States v. Reed. Therefore, the evidence about Mr. Markey’s belief is not sufficient for exoneration.

In A. 598 (1935), this Court determined that a graduated income tax violated the Uniformity Clause. The statute in question taxed income below $5,000 at 2%, income between $5,000 and $10,000 at 2.5%, and income from $10,000 to $25,000 at 3%. The Kelley Court stated that the tax was non-uniform because it taxed those with incomes above a certain threshold simply because the Legislature deemed their incomes sufficiently high for taxation. Id. at 602. Based on Kelley, we later invalidated a city ordinance that imposed a tax on "every individual engaged in an occupation . . . whose gross earnings would amount to $600 or more during the year" in Saulsbury v. Bethlehem Steel Co., 413 Pa. 316, 196 A.2d 664 (1964) (<HOLDING>). More recently, in Amidon, supra, this Court

If scientific testimony is based on established scientific principles or techniques, the Rimmasch test does not apply. See id.; see also State v. Adams, 2000 UT 42, ¶ 16, 5 P.3d 642 (<HOLDING>). In such cases, the testimony merely needs to adhere to the relevant standards.

In the landmark case of Dawco Construction, Inc. v. United States, the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit clarified that the Contract Disputes Act (CDA) designates the individual responsible for making the final decision on a dispute. Specifically, the court highlighted that once a claim is initiated, it must be submitted to the contracting officer, who then holds the authority to render the final decision. This principle was outlined in Dawco Construction, Inc. v. United States, 930 F.2d 872, 880 (Fed. Cir. 1991) (emphasis added), although it was later revised in part by Reflectone, Inc., 60 F.3d at 1579.

With this framework in mind, the court examined whether Kemron had properly submitted a "claim" to the contracting officer, thereby fulfilling the necessary jurisdictional requirements to pursue a CDA claim for nonmonetary relief. This analysis is found in Record Steel & Construction, Inc. v. United States, 62 Fed. Cl. 508, 520 (2004), and is further supported by precedent in Todd Construction, L.P., 85 Fed. Cl. at 42.

Under Pa.R.A.P. 3781(a), the drama unfolds when the Liquidator issues a notice of determination (NOD). Not taking this lightly, AIGA files an objection per Pa.R.A.P. 3781(c), arguing that the entire claim, including post-judgment interest, should be accepted and assigned priority level (b).

In a decisive move, the referee dismisses AIGA’s claims as waived, leaving the courtroom hanging on the edge of this legal cliffhanger.

If official immunity were understood only in the limited sense used by the court of appeals, public officers' protection from personal civil liability would be meaningless. Although it does not directly state that Mooney failed in his duty to assist clients with their investments, this is strongly implied by the specific language used. This implication becomes explicit in the following statement — “didn’t know anything about investments.” The phrase “hated helping clients” clearly indicates Mooney's lack of interest in fulfilling his responsibilities to his clients. For judges, managing trials and overseeing lawyers can pose significant challenges, sometimes necessitating firm measures that may appear severe or even oppressive. Implementing a stringent standard that reserves sanctions solely for instances of overtly abusive conduct can help to ensure that councils do not unfairly penalize appropriate actions due to inexperience. Moreover, beyond the issue of inexperience, it is essential to recognize that judges themselves are capable of unfair—sometimes even vengeful—behavior towards their peers. By adhering to a rigorous standard, we can mitigate, though not entirely prevent, the misuse of judicial discipline as a tool for targeting unpopular judges who are nonetheless acting appropriately. Additionally, like the threat of civil liability for judicial actions, judicial discipline can deter judges from exercising their discretion properly. This concern is underscored by the precedent established in Pierson v. Ray, 386 U.S. 547, 553-54, 87 S.Ct. 1213, 18 L.Ed.2d 288 (1967), and echoes the caution noted in Williams v. United States, 156 F.3d 86.

To appeal issues related to his waiver and the sua sponte dismissal, we should reject the petitioner’s arguments on the merits. In my view, the district court's actions were in line not only with AEDPA but also with the related case law. Congress intended AEDPA to promote the principles of comity, finality, and federalism. As noted in Williams v. Taylor, 529 U.S. 420, 436 (2000), "there is no doubt Congress intended AEDPA to advance these doctrines [comity, finality, and federalism]." To support this purpose, Congress established a one-year limitations period aimed at streamlining the habeas review process and providing finality to state court convictions. This objective is affirmed in Duncan v. Walker, 533 U.S. 167, 121 S.Ct. 2120, 2128 (2001); see also H.R. Cong. Rep. No. 104-518, at 111.

The evidence of Robertson’s alleged prior threat to his ex-wife, presented as Williams rule evidence, cannot be introduced under the guise of impeachment by posing impermissible questions regarding an alleged prior crime. The State’s attempt to introduce such evidence through the back door is not permissible. Furthermore, we must consider whether the admission of this collateral-crime evidence constitutes reversible error. This Court has consistently held that the erroneous admission of irrelevant collateral crimes evidence is presumed to be harmful error due to the significant risk that a jury will view the defendant's bad character or propensity for crime as proof of guilt for the charged offense. This position is supported by precedent in Castro v. State, 547 So.2d 111, 115 (Fla.1989), quoting Straight v. State, 397 So.2d 903, 908 (Fla.1981), and similarly upheld in Czubak v. State, 570 So.2d 925, 928 (Fla.1990). In the present case, given the highly inflammatory nature of such evidence, its erroneous admission cannot be overlooked.

The argument that employees’ grievances over working conditions are shielded by the First Amendment is not supported here. The idea is that a public employee cannot convert a personal complaint into a public issue just by suggesting that it relates to public interest in the functioning of public institutions. The key question to consider is not whether the public would find the topic of the speech interesting, but whether the employee’s intention in speaking was to highlight issues of public concern. In this case, the evidence suggests that although the plaintiffs’ speech seemingly touched on child safety and mismanagement within the DeKalb DFCS, the true intent was not to address these issues from the standpoint of a concerned citizen. This perspective aligns with the decision in *White Plains Towing Corp. v. In accordance with the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, we will review the allegations made by the plaintiffs under this amendment, claiming that the defendants have violated their due process rights. 

5. Plaintiffs' Procedural Due Process Rights Under the Fourteenth Amendment

The plaintiffs have presented several claims of procedural due process violations by the defendants. These include being compelled to participate in a five-phase treatment program at Atascadero, being forced to take medication in non-emergency situations, and experiencing reductions in privileges, access levels, and changes in classification. The plaintiffs assert that these actions are taken without giving them sufficient notice or an opportunity to address the accusations of the conduct that warranted the sanctions. According to the Fourteenth Amendment, plaintiffs might possess a liberty interest in this context.

The Wisconsin Supreme Court defines an issue as "joined" between parties when a formal pleading requesting relief is served by one party against another. See Gies v. Nissen Corp., 57 Wis.2d 371, 204 N.W.2d 519, 525 (1973). This means that the issue is formally recognized and controverted when both parties have clearly stated their positions. For example, in the Gies case, the first co-defendant, by serving a cross-claim for contribution against the second co-defendant, effectively joined the issue of their respective liabilities to the plaintiff. Consequently, the first co-defendant was bound by the judgment that dismissed the second co-defendant. The requirement of a formal pleading ensures that any requested relief is explicitly stated and that either party can enforce it. See, e.g., Goldblatt, 417 N.W.2d at 419 (<HOLDING>). In the case of the Streitzes and Marshall, they did not engage in formal pleading.

It concluded that the insurer was not obligated to pay for the inherent diminution in market value because the insurer’s liability was limited to either the actual cash value of the property or the amount necessary to repair or replace it with like kind and quality. Bronster, 82 Hawai’i at 40, 919 P.2d at 302, elaborates on the concept that damage to a product simply signifies it has not met the customer's expectations, indicating that the customer has received a product of insufficient value. According to this ruling, under the economic loss rule, a manufacturer engaged in a commercial relationship bears no duty, whether under negligence or strict products liability theories, to prevent a product from harming itself. This principle was further supported in Leis Family Ltd. Partnership v. Silversword Engineering, 126 Hawai’i 532, 538-39, 273 P.3d 1218, 1224-25 (Haw.Ct.App.2012), which cited the same precedent from Bronster, 82 Hawai’i at 39, 919 P.2d at 301. The economic loss rule similarly extends to claims based on negligent design and/or manufacturing, as noted in Bronster, 82 Hawai’i at 40, 919 P.2d at 302, and to claims of negligent misrepresentation, as held in City Express, 87 Hawai’i at 470, 959 P.2d at 840. The Hawaii Supreme Court's most recent decisions reflect and uphold these legal principles.

In evaluating the sufficiency of an indictment, legal precedent highlights the necessity of ensuring that the allegations clearly convey the charges to a jury. As established in United States v. Young, the court must verify that the indictment's allegations can adequately inform the jury about the specific offense (694 F.Supp.2d 25, 27 (D.Me.2010), citing Boyce Motor Lines, Inc. v. United States, 342 U.S. 337, 343 n. 16, 72 S.Ct. 329, 96 L.Ed. 367 (1952)). For an indictment to be deemed sufficient, it must outline the elements of the charged offense and provide sufficient detail to inform the defendant of the charges faced, as emphasized in United States v. Sampson (371 U.S. 75, 76, 83 S.Ct. 173, 9 L.Ed.2d 136 (1962)) and United States v. Barker Steel Co., Inc. (985 F.2d 1123, 1125 (1st Cir.1993)). Furthermore, the indictment must enable the defendant to use an acquittal or conviction as a defense against any future prosecutions for the same offense. This standard was underscored in Hamling v. United States (418 U.S. 87, 117, 94 S.Ct. 2887, 41 L.Ed.2d 590 (1974)) and reaffirmed by the Teleguz court in upholding section 922(k).

As a result, up until July 25, 1973, the day following Dr. Elizabeth's death, Freberg's right to sue the Thomasons had not yet come into existence, meaning the statute of limitations had not started. In fact, the limitations period for Freberg didn't begin until he was stopped from continuing his work. Refer to Scott v. Walker for a similar case. To decide that Freberg's right to sue was established after each day’s work would unnecessarily break down the time frame for these continuous tasks. For further reference, see Jones v. Lewis, 11 Tex. 359 (1854); Caldwell v. Jones, 63 S.W.2d 761 (Tex.Civ.App. — Amarillo 1933, writ ref’d); Annot., 99 A.L.R.2d 251, 253 (1965).

Determining whether a case meets the statutory requirements for restitution is a legal question that the appellate court can fully review. See State v. Nelson, 796 N.W.2d 343, 346-47 (Minn.App.2011). Under Minn. Stat. § 611A.04, subd. 1(a), a victim is permitted to request restitution if a defendant is convicted of a crime. In reviewing such requests, courts consider several factors, including “the amount of economic loss sustained by the victim as a result of the offense,” as specified in Minn. Stat. § 611A.045, subd. 1(a)(1) (2012). The courts have interpreted the statute to mean that the claimed loss must be “directly caused by the conduct for which the defendant was convicted.” See State v.
